description: From Middle English churlysshe, cherlissh, from late Old English ċeorlisċ, ċierlisċ (“of or pertaining to churls”), equivalent to churl +‎ -ish.

adjectives.description: churlish (comparative more churlish, superlative most churlish)

entries.meaning: Of or pertaining to a serf, peasant, or rustic.
examples: […]  the eloquence and truth of his tribute stands in marked contrast to Kramer's churlish caricature of Kael as a happy pig wallowing in the dirt.
Synonyms: grudging, illiberal, miserly, niggardly, stingy

entries.meaning: (of soil) Difficult to till, lacking pliancy; unmanageable.
examples: Where the bleak Swiss their stormy mansion tread,
And force a churlish soil for scanty bread.
